messages: 0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (14:09): changes: hixie: Make the microdata DOM API more consistent with other APIs. (camelCase) (whatwg r4139) <http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-diffs/2009Oct/0060.html>
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:16): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, out of curiosity: what's the status of the RDFa-in-HTML WPWD?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:18): 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28: will be published tomorrow
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:19): btw, it seems I will be attending the HyBi and IRI BOFs at IETF 76
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:31): Mike, would you know if we had WG members with ePub format background?

0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (14:39): changes: hixie: Microdata: Rename .content to .itemValue and make it more useful. (whatwg r4140) <http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-diffs/2009Oct/0061.html>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:45): 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28: fyi, the IETF actually asked us to move websockets to the IETF. So we already know they want to standardise it.
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (14:45): Maybe they just want to kill it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:46): they're not going about it very effectively if so :-)
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:53): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, but "moving it" implies that the actuall spec development happens in the IETF, not somewhere else.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:54): If you just want to *publish* through the IETF, the answer usually is "use Informational RFC".
9bb295af93051e68de66b2bd517b2e24 (14:54): isn't it discussed on hybi then?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:55): This was about a mail where Ian told us about feedback he got from people outside the mailing list.
9bb295af93051e68de66b2bd517b2e24 (14:56): isn't that always the case?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:57): 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28: personally i'd like to publish in the w3c
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:57): 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28: it's the IETF who wants us to publish through the IETF

60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:58): Feedback from outside is ok, as long its handled properly. If this was a WG, and there wasn't consensus for something, the chairs would have a hard time with this.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:58): So if this is supposed to become an IETF thing, the people working on it should have their discussion there.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:59): An IETF WG usually is not a publication mechanism for things developed somewhere else.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:59): It's possible to do so, but then that should be reflected in the charter.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:00): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, "publish through the IETF" can mean many things; an Informational RFC is one of these.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:00): "Informational RFC" is the same as a W3C Note, right?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:00): i.e. it's meaningless, normatively?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:02): no, it's not meaningless
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:02): It's just not on the IETF standards track
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:02): what's the value of the IETF standards track?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:02): If you choose to implement it, it's normative. If you don't, it isn't. That isn't different from anything else.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:03): basically, why would i care one way or the other?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:03): More control by the IESG, presumably.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:03): I think for most people, it really doesn't matter.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:04): then why did you bring it up?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:04): i'm confused
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:05): Because it matters to the IETF, and to the WG-to-be. The point of forming a WG is to produce standards track documents here.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:05): why does it matter to the WG-to-be?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:05): and why does it matter to the IETF?

60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:07): If a WG is formed in order to define a bidirectional protocol, then the assumption is that it'll be developed according to the IETF process rules. If it isn't then this should be called out in the charter beforehand.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:07): And, of course, one of the reasons why process *does* matter is IPR.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:08): and the IETF process rules prevent people from having conversations with a spec's editor outside the list?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:09): But just because they do not prevent it doesn't mean it's a good thing when people of significance to the spec development do that outside the process

0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (15:09): changes: hixie: Remove 'loadend' event from media elements. (whatwg r4142) <http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-diffs/2009Oct/0063.html> ** hixie: Fix scripted examples for microdata (whatwg r4141) <http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-diffs/2009Oct/0062.html>
0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (15:09): bugmail: [Bug 7917] New: document.close() should attempt to tokenize <http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-bugzilla/2009Oct/0190.html>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:10): and that would be a reason for the WG to not work on that spec?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:10): it seems weird that you would suggest that the WG would want to _not_ work on the spec that is getting implementor feedback, even if that feedback is off-list
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:12): what I said is that if people who are important for the contents of the spec do not want to do that on the WG's mailing list, that will be a problem.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:12): the simplest way to fix this is to encourage them to join the mailing list.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:12): you went further than that, you said it would be grounds to not maket it a WG deliverable
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:12): I think that's pretty easy to grasp, so I'm not sure how else to explain it

60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:13): If the spec is known to be developed somewhere else, it would be a reason not to treat it as if developed by the WG, and then it would be harder to put it onto the standards track.

60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:15): how about addressing the issue, by agreeing that, *if* there'll be a WG, and *if* that WG wants to work on that spec, discussion should move to the WG's mailing list?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:15): is there a problem with that?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:16): discussion will happen where discussion happens
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:16): i'm not going to ignore people talking to me
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:17): so how do you deal with the IPR issue?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:17): what IPR issue?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:18): http://www.ietf.org/about/note-well.html
0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (15:18): Title: Note Well (at www.ietf.org)
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:18): there's a problem if you take input that hasn't been submitted according to these rules
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:18): could you be more precise? that page doesn't have any rules on it, and links to 37 pages' worth of rules
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:19): don't be silly, the IETF doesn't require that we ignore feedback from outside the IETF
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:19): that would be ridiculous
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:19): I was talking about contributions
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:20): i write every word of the spec
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:20): does that address the IPR concern?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:20): that doesn't make you the owner of the IPR
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:21): anyway, this is something you'll need to discuss with the WG chairs and area directors, not me
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:22): well, you brought it up :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:22): i don't know what you mean by "contributions"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:22): if feedback doesn't count
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:22): and text isn't it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:22): but i'm happy to not discuss it, i was only doing so because you mentioned it
9bb295af93051e68de66b2bd517b2e24 (15:22): it's features prolly
9bb295af93051e68de66b2bd517b2e24 (15:23): just like at W3C
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:23): feedback contains features, so that can't be it
9bb295af93051e68de66b2bd517b2e24 (15:23): maybe 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 makes some distinction there
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:31): do the other people on HyBi still want to do reverse HTTP instead of WebSocket?

0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (15:39): bugmail: [Bug 7902] ijhugytfdsdfgdsd <http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-bugzilla/2009Oct/0192.html> ** [Bug 7894] what is <http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-bugzilla/2009Oct/0191.html>

0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (15:41): planet: View Source Tutorial: Sticky Notes With HTML5 and CSS3 <http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/ajaxian/~3/rq8ioDc5ASg/view-source-tutorial-sticky-notes-with-html5-and-css3>
